[[Pat Hare]] |website = [http://www.jamescottonsuperharp.com/ Official website] |current_members = |past_members = }} [[File:James Cotton One.jpg|thumb|right|In [[Delray Beach]], Florida]] '''James Cotton''' (born July 1, 1935){{cite web|author=Bill Dahl |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/james-cotton-mn0000131841/biography |title=James Cotton | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1935-07-01 |accessdate=2014-05-16}} is an American [[blues]] [[harmonica]] player, singer and songwriter, who has performed and recorded with many of the great blues artists of his time as well as with his own band. Although he played drums early in his career, Cotton is famous for his work on the harmonica. Cotton began his professional career playing the [[blues harp]] in [[Howlin' Wolf]]'s band in the early 1950s. In 1965 he formed the Jimmy Cotton Blues Quartet, utilizing [[Otis Spann]] on piano to record between gigs with Muddy Waters' band. In the 1970s, Cotton played harmonica on Muddy Waters' [[Grammy Award]] winning 1977 album ''[[Hard Again]]'', produced by [[Johnny Winter]]. ==Career== Born in [[Tunica, Mississippi]], [[United States]], Cotton became interested in music when he first heard [[Sonny Boy Williamson II]] on the radio. He left home with his uncle and moved to [[West Helena, Arkansas]], finding Williamson there. For many years Cotton claimed that he told Williamson that he was an orphan, and that Williamson took him in and raised him; a story he admitted in recent years is not true. Williamson did however mentor Cotton during his early years.{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues – From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher=Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | page= 103 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} When Williamson left the south to live with his estranged wife in [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]], he left his band in Cotton's hands. Cotton was quoted as saying, "He just gave it to me. But I couldn't hold it together 'cause I was too young and crazy in those days an' everybody in the band was grown men, so much older than me." [[File:James Cotton - Hondarribia 2008-07-19.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Cotton performing in 2008]] Although he played drums early in his career, Cotton is famous for his work on the harmonica. Cotton began his professional career playing the [[blues harp]] in [[Howlin' Wolf]]'s band in the early 1950s. He made his first recordings as a solo artist for the [[Sun Records]] label in [[Memphis, Tennessee]] in 1953. In 1954, he recorded an [[electric blues]] record "[[:File:File:James Cotton - Cotton Crop Blues.ogg|Cotton Crop Blues]]" which featured a heavily [[distortion|distorted]] [[power chord]]-driven [[electric guitar]] solo by [[Pat Hare]].Robert Palmer, "Church of the Sonic Guitar", pp. 13-38 in Anthony DeCurtis, ''Present Tense'', Duke University Press, 1992, pp. 24-27. ISBN 0-8223-1265-4. Cotton began to work with the [[Muddy Waters]] Band around 1955. He performed songs such as "[[Got My Mojo Working]]" and "[[She's Nineteen Years Old]]", although he did not appear on the original recordings; long-time Muddy Waters harmonica player [[Little Walter]] was utilized on most of Muddy's recording sessions in the 1950s. Cotton's first recording session with Waters took place in June 1957, and he would alternate with Little Walter on Muddy's recording sessions until the end of the decade, and thereafter until he left to form his own band. In 1965 he formed the Jimmy Cotton Blues Quartet, utilizing [[Otis Spann]] on piano to record between gigs with Muddy Waters' band. Their performances were captured by [[record producer|producer]] [[Samuel Charters]] on volume two of the [[Vanguard Records|Vanguard]] recording ''Chicago/The Blues/Today!''. After leaving Muddy's band in 1966, Cotton toured with [[Janis Joplin]] while pursuing a solo career. He formed the James Cotton Blues Band in 1967. They mainly performed their own arrangements of popular blues and [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] material from the 1950s and 1960s. Two albums were recorded live in [[Montreal]] that year. In the 1960s, Cotton formed a blues band in the tradition of [[Bobby Bland]]. After Bland's death, his son told news media that Bland had recently discovered that James Cotton was his half-brother.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/25/arts/music/bobby-blue-bland-soul-and-blues-balladeer-dies-at-83.html |title=Bobby (Blue) Bland, Soul and Blues Balladeer, Dies at 83 |newspaper=New York Times|date=June 24, 2013 |first=Bill |last=Friskics-Warren}} Four tracks that featured the big band horn sound and traditional songs were captured on the album ''Two Sides of the Blue''. [[Image:James Cotton.jpg|thumb|220px|right|James Cotton at [[Jeff Healey]]'s blues nightclub in [[Toronto]]]] In the 1970s, Cotton recorded several albums with [[Buddah Records]]. Cotton played harmonica on Muddy Waters' [[Grammy Award]] winning 1977 album ''[[Hard Again]]'', produced by [[Johnny Winter]]. The James Cotton Blues Band received a Grammy nomination in 1984 for ''Live From Chicago: Mr. Superharp Himself!'', and a second for his 1987 release, ''Take Me Back''. He finally was awarded a Grammy for ''Deep in the Blues'' in 1996 for [[Best Traditional Blues Album]].[http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/musician.php?id=5941]{{dead link|date=March 2014}} Cotton appeared on the cover of ''Living Blues'' magazine in 1987 in the July/August issue (#76).{{cite web|url=http://livingblues.com/backissues/03_BI64-96/076.html |title=James Cotton Interview |publisher=Livingblues.com |accessdate=2014-05-16}} He was featured in the same publication's 40th anniversary issue, released in 2010 in August/September. Cotton battled throat cancer in the mid-1990s, and his last recorded vocal performance was on 2000's ''Fire Down Under the Hill'', but he continued to tour, utilizing singers or his backing band members as vocalists. Cotton's studio album, ''Giant'', was released on Alligator Records in late September 2010. His latest album, also on Alligator Records, "Cotton Mouth Man" was released on May 7, 2013. It includes guest appearances by Gregg Allman, Joe Bonamassa, Ruthie Foster, Delbert McClinton, Warren Haynes, Keb Mo, Chuck Leavell and Colin Linden.{{cite web|url=http://alligatorrecords.com/index.cfm?section=news&newsID=448 |title=Genuine Houserockin' Music Since 1971 |publisher=Alligator Records |date= |accessdate=2014-05-16}} On March 10, 2008, Cotton and [[Ben Harper]] inducted [[Little Walter]] into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]]. They performed "[[Juke (song)|Juke]]" and "[[My Babe]]" together at the induction ceremony which was broadcast nationwide on [[VH1 Classic]]. On August 30, 2010, Cotton was the special guest on Larry Monroe's farewell broadcast of ''Blue Monday'' which he hosted on [[KUT]] in Austin, Texas for nearly 30 years.[http://kut.org/items/show/22298]{{dead link|date=March 2014}} Cotton appeared on the debut album by The Dr. Izzy Band, ''Blind & Blues Bound''. Released in June, 2013, he played harp on the opening song "Matches Don't Burn Memories".{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.musiconthecouch.com/2013/09/92313-dr-izzy-robert-morrison-sat-on.html |title=9/23/13 Dr Izzy & Robert Morrison Sat On The Couch |publisher=Music On The Couch |date=2013-09-23 |accessdate=2014-05-16}} In 2014, Cotton was nominated for a [[Blues Music Award]] in the 'Best Instrumentalist – Harmonica' category.{{cite web|url=http://blues.about.com/od/bluesawards/a/2014-Blues-Music-Awards.htm |title=2014 Blues Music Awards Nominees and Winners |publisher=Blues.about.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-16}} ==Musical company== Cotton has worked with many prominent artists including: {{multicol}} * [[Big Mama Thornton]] * [[Janis Joplin]] * [[Sonny Boy Williamson II|Sonny Boy Williamson]] * [[Howlin' Wolf]] * [[Muddy Waters]] * [[Otis Spann]] * [[Mike Bloomfield]] * [[Quicksilver Messenger Service]] * [[Freddie King]] * [[Steve Miller (musician)|Steve Miller]] * [[Carlos Santana|Santana]] * [[B.B.
